messages.user_message: What is the appropriate nozzle temperature for 3D printing using fused deposition modeling with polylactic acid (PLA)?
messages.assistant_response: The appropriate nozzle temperature for 3D printing using fused deposition modeling with polylactic acid (PLA) generally ranges from 190째C to 230째C. However, the optimum temperature can vary based on several factors such as bed temperature, surrounding temperature, printing speed, and the plastic's crystallinity and thermal properties. A recent optimization study found that pure PLA prints had the best properties at a temperature of 215째C. It is important to note that increasing the nozzle temperature to 240째C can make PLA 3D-printed parts more durable, but exceeding this temperature may lead to polymer degradation [reference_188.pdf, page 784].

messages.user_message: What is the appropriate printing speed for 3D printing using fused deposition modeling with polylactic acid (PLA)?
messages.assistant_response: The appropriate printing speed for 3D printing using fused deposition modeling with polylactic acid (PLA) can vary, but a commonly used infill speed is 90 mm/s, which has been found to provide the highest Young's modulus for pure PLA. In the range of 70 to 110 mm/s, 90 mm/s was identified as optimal for mechanical properties. However, it is important to note that the strength of samples tends to decrease with increasing speed, especially above 80 mm/s, where it decreases significantly [reference_120.pdf, page 284; reference_130.pdf, page 1].

messages.user_message: What is the appropriate layer height for 3D printing using fused deposition modeling with polylactic acid (PLA)?
messages.assistant_response: The appropriate layer height for 3D printing using fused deposition modeling with polylactic acid (PLA) can vary depending on the desired surface quality and print time. In a study, the layer height was varied from 0.05 mm to 0.25 mm. It was found that a smaller layer height, such as 0.05 mm, resulted in smoother surfaces, while a larger layer height, such as 0.25 mm, resulted in rougher surfaces. Additionally, the printing time is inversely proportional to surface roughness, meaning that smaller layer heights will increase the printing time [reference_145.pdf, page 2].
